description: From Middle English loof (“weather gage, windward direction”), probably from Middle Dutch (Compare Dutch loef (“the weather side of a ship”)), originally a nautical order to keep the ship's head to the wind, thus to stay clear of a lee-shore or some other quarter, hence the figurative sense of "at a distance, apart".

adjectives.description: aloof (comparative more aloof, superlative most aloof)

entries.meaning: Reserved and remote; either physically or emotionally distant; standoffish.

adverbs.description: aloof (comparative more aloof, superlative most aloof)

entries.meaning: At or from a distance, but within view, or at a small distance; apart; away.
